name: General Knowledge 101 Quiz | Mixed 20 Questions | 20 Questions

questions.text: What is the longest river in Asia?
questions.explanation:
Yangtze.

	The Yangtze is 3,720 miles long, just longer than the Ob-Irtysh at 3,360 miles.

questions.text: In computer talk what does 'C.P.U.' stand for?
questions.explanation: Central Processing Unit.

questions.text: What is a 'fluffy duck'?
questions.explanation:
Cocktail.

	Made from 30ml Bacardi, 30ml Advocaat, lemonade, cream and ice.

questions.text: Who did Andre Agassi play in the semi-finals of Wimbledon for three years running (ending with 2001)?
questions.explanation:
Pat Rafter.

	Pat won twice, then gone on to lose the final unfortunately.

questions.text: In what ocean is the deepest point on earth?
questions.explanation:
Pacific Ocean.

	The Marianas Trench is measured at 36,198 feet or 11,033 metres.

questions.text: What does the word 'Kamikaze' literally mean in Japanese?
questions.explanation:
Divine Wind.

	Used in World War Two, Japanese pilots would dive bomb enemy ships with their planes heavily laden with explosives.

questions.text: Who won the men's 200m freestyle at the 2000 Olympics in Sydney?
questions.explanation:
Pieter van den Hoogenband.

	Pieter touched out Ian in an absolute thriller.

questions.text: Lightning strikes from the ground up.
questions.explanation:
True.

	I know I didn't believe it at first either, but do some research and you'll be surprised.

questions.text: In what year did the Titanic sink?
questions.explanation:
1912.

	The unsinkable ship had two sisters - the Brittanic was torpedoed when a hospital ship in the Mediterranean in WWI and the Olympic was finally scrapped after a long life in 1935.

questions.text: Which of the following countries did NOT compete in the 1896 Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: China.

questions.text: In which country was Adolf Hitler born?
questions.explanation: Austria.

questions.text: Which of these bear species is the largest?
questions.explanation: Polar Bear.

questions.text: After whom was the Nobel Prize named?
questions.explanation:
Alfred Nobel.

	He was the inventor of dynamite, and because of this he established the Peace Prize.

questions.text: What is the last letter of the Greek alphabet?
questions.explanation:
Omega.

	Did you know that there are 24 letters in the Greek alphabet?

questions.text: What is the total surface area of the earth (including water)?
Which of these is not one of the seven natural wonders of the world?
questions.explanation:
Hanging Gardens of Babylon.

	The Hanging Gardens of Babylon is actually one of the Ancient Wonders of the world.  Victoria Falls is the largest waterfall in the world, the Great Barrier Reef is the largest living organism in the world, and the Grand Canyon is just as it sounds - a grand canyon!

questions.text: Which three countries made up the 'Axis Powers' in World War Two?
questions.explanation: Germany, Italy and Japan.

questions.text: What is said to be the oldest race in the world?
questions.explanation:
Australian Aborigines.

	The Australian Aborigines have history dating back at least 40,000 years.

questions.text: Who was born with the name Cassius Clay?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Ali.

questions.text: If the continents were placed in alphabetical order, which one would come first?
questions.explanation:
Africa.

	The USA teaches these continents: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America. Other countries put North and South America together in one continent, and call 'Australia' Oceania.
